name.en: Modeling and Identification of Dynamic Systems

goal.ch:
This course provides an in-depth exploration of techniques for modeling and identifying dynamic systems, with a focus on understanding the underlying physical principles and mathematical representations. The course covers a range of methods for developing models of dynamic systems from first principles and experimental data, emphasizing both theoretical and practical aspects.
Course Objectives:
To understand the principles of dynamic system modeling.
To learn various methods for identifying dynamic systems from experimental data.
To apply modeling and identification techniques to real-world systems.
To develop skills in using computational tools for system modeling and identification.
goal.en:
This course provides an in-depth exploration of techniques for modeling and identifying dynamic systems, with a focus on understanding the underlying physical principles and mathematical representations. The course covers a range of methods for developing models of dynamic systems from first principles and experimental data, emphasizing both theoretical and practical aspects.
Course Objectives:
To understand the principles of dynamic system modeling.
To learn various methods for identifying dynamic systems from experimental data.
To apply modeling and identification techniques to real-world systems.
To develop skills in using computational tools for system modeling and identification.

outline.ch:
Introduction to Dynamic Systems:
Overview of dynamic systems and their importance.
Classification of dynamic systems (linear vs. nonlinear, time-invariant vs. time-variant).
Basic concepts in system dynamics (state, input, output, transfer function).
Mathematical Modeling of Dynamic Systems:
Derivation of models from first principles (mechanical, electrical, thermal, and fluid systems).
Linearization of nonlinear systems.
State-space representation and transfer function models.
Block diagrams and signal flow graphs.
System Identification Techniques:
Time-domain methods (e.g., least squares, Kalman filtering).
Frequency-domain methods (e.g., spectral analysis, Bode plots).
Parametric vs. non-parametric identification methods.
Model validation and selection criteria.
Stochastic Modeling and System Identification:
Introduction to stochastic processes in dynamic systems.
Identification of systems with noise and disturbances.
Maximum likelihood estimation and other statistical methods.
Computational Tools for System Modeling and Identification:
MATLAB/Simulink for system modeling and identification.
Data acquisition and processing techniques.
Application of software tools to real-world problems.
Case Studies and Applications:
Application of modeling and identification techniques in engineering systems (e.g., mechanical, aerospace, automotive).
Case studies of real-world systems and their identification.
Group projects focusing on modeling and identification of a specific dynamic system.

textbook.ch:
Ljung, L. “System Identification: Theory for the User.“ Prentice Hall, 1999.
Ogata, K. “System Dynamics.“ Prentice Hall, 2014.
Franklin, G. F., Powell, J. D., and Emami-Naeini, A. “Feedback Control of Dynamic Systems.“ Pearson, 2019.
textbook.en:
Ljung, L. “System Identification: Theory for the User.“ Prentice Hall, 1999.
Ogata, K. “System Dynamics.“ Prentice Hall, 2014.
Franklin, G. F., Powell, J. D., and Emami-Naeini, A. “Feedback Control of Dynamic Systems.“ Pearson, 2019.
